           <div class="publication-abstract" data-reactid="147">
            <div class="nova-e-text nova-e-text--size-xl nova-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-e-text--spacing-xs" data-reactid="148">
             Abstract
            </div>
            <div class="nova-e-text nova-e-text--size-m nova-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-e-text--spacing-auto" data-reactid="149">
             The continued progress in developing technological platforms, availability of many published experimental datasets, as well as different statistical methods to analyze those data have allowed approaching the same research question using various methods simultaneously. To get the best out of all these alternatives, we need to integrate their results in an unbiased manner. Prioritized gene lists are a common result presentation method in genomic data analysis applications. Thus, the rank aggregation methods can become a useful and general solution for the integration task. Standard rank aggregation methods are often ill-suited for biological settings where the gene lists are inherently noisy. As a remedy, we propose a novel robust rank aggregation (RRA) method. Our method detects genes that are ranked consistently better than expected under null hypothesis of uncorrelated inputs and assigns a significance score for each gene. The underlying probabilistic model makes the algorithm parameter free and robust to outliers, noise and errors. Significance scores also provide a rigorous way to keep only the statistically relevant genes in the final list. These properties make our approach robust and compelling for many settings. All the methods are implemented as a GNU R package RobustRankAggreg, freely available at the Comprehensive R Archive Network http://cran.r-project.org/.
            </div>

              <div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws0">
               [15:15 9/2/2012 Bioinformatics-btr709.tex]
               <span class="_ _0"> </span>Page:
               <span class="_ _1"> </span>573
               <span class="_ _2"> </span>573–580
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h3 y2 ff2 fs1 fc1 sc0 ls9 ws1">
               BIOINFORMA
               <span class="_ _3"></span>TICS 
               <span class="fc0 ws2">ORIGINAL P<span class="_ _3"></span>APER<span class="_ _4"> </span><span class="ff3 fs2 ws3 v1">Vol. 28 no. 4 2012, pages 573–580</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 h4 y3 ff3 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws4">
               doi:10.1093/bioinformatics/btr709
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h5 y4 ff3 fs3 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws5">
               Data and text mining
               <span class="_ _5"> </span>
               <span class="ff4 fs2 ws3">Advance Access publication January 12, 2012</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h6 y5 ff5 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws6">
               Robust rank aggregation for gene list integration and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h6 y6 ff5 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               meta-analysis
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h7 y7 ff6 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws7">
               Raivo Kolde
               <span class="fs6 ws8 v2">1<span class="ff7 ws9">,<span class="ff6 ls1">2</span></span></span>
               <span class="v0">, Sven Laur<span class="fs6 ls2 v2">1</span>, Priit Adler<span class="fs6 ws8 v2">1<span class="ff7 ws9">,<span class="ff6 ls3">3</span></span></span>and Jaak Vilo<span class="fs6 ws8 v2">1<span class="ff7 ws9">,</span>2<span class="ff7 ws9">,<span class="ff8">?</span></span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h8 y8 ff6 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls4">
               1
               <span class="fs7 ls9 wsa v3">Institute of Computer Science, University of T<span class="_ _3"></span>artu, Liivi 2- 314, 50409 T<span class="_ _3"></span>artu, <span class="fs2 ls5 v4">2</span>Quretec, Ülikooli 6a, 51003 T<span class="_ _3"></span>artu and</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h9 y9 ff6 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls4">
               3
               <span class="fs7 ls9 wsa v3">Institute of Molecular and Cell Biology<span class="_ _3"></span>, University of T<span class="_ _3"></span>artu, Riia 23, 51010 T<span class="_ _3"></span>artu, Estonia</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h9 ya ff6 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               Associate Editor: Jonathan Wren
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 yb ff5 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               ABSTRACT
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 yc ff5 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsb">
               Motivation: 
               <span class="ff4 wsc">The continued progress in developing technological</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 yd ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd">
               platforms, availability of many published experimental datasets, as
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 ye ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse">
               well as different statistical methods to analyze those data have
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 yf ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsf">
               allowed approaching the same research question using various
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y10 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws10">
               methods simultaneously. T
               <span class="_ _3"></span>o get the best out of all these alternatives,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y11 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws11">
               we need to integrate their results in an unbiased manner
               <span class="_ _3"></span>. Prioritized
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y12 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws12">
               gene lists are a common result presentation method in genomic
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y13 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws13">
               data analysis applications. Thus, the rank aggregation methods can
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y14 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               become a useful and general solution for the integration task.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y15 ff5 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws14">
               Results: 
               <span class="ff4 ws15">Standard rank aggregation methods are often ill-suited for</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y16 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws16">
               biological settings where the gene lists are inherently noisy
               <span class="_ _3"></span>. As a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y17 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws17">
               remedy, we pr
               <span class="_ _3"></span>opose a novel robust rank aggregation (RRA) method.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y18 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws18">
               Our method detects genes that are ranked consistently better than
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y19 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws19">
               expected under null hypothesis of uncorrelated inputs and assigns a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y1a ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a">
               signi?cance score for each gene. The underlying probabilistic model
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y1b ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b">
               makes the algorithm parameter free and robust to outliers, noise and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y1c ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1c">
               errors. Signi?cance scores also provide a rigorous way to keep only
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y1d ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d">
               the statistically relevant genes in the ?nal list. These properties make
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y1e ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               our approach robust and compelling for many settings.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y1f ff5 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e">
               Availability: 
               <span class="ff4 ws1f">All the methods are implemented as a GNU R package</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y20 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls6">
               R
               <span class="fs0 ls0 ws20 v0">OBUST</span>
               <span class="v0">R<span class="fs0 ls0 ws20">ANK</span><span class="ls7">A<span class="fs0 ls0 ws20">GGREG</span><span class="ls9 ws21">, freely available at the Comprehensive R Archive</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y21 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               Network http://cran.r-project.or
               <span class="_ _3"></span>g/.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y22 ff5 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws22">
               Contact: 
               <span class="ff4">vilo@ut.ee</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y23 ff5 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws23">
               Supplementary information
               <span class="_ _6"> </span>
               <span class="ff4">Supplementary data are available at</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y24 ff3 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws24">
               Bioinformatics 
               <span class="ff4">online.</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y25 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws25">
               Received on April 23, 2011; revised on November 28, 2011; accepted
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h4 y26 ff4 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               on December 21, 2011
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 ha y27 ff5 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws26">
               1 INTRODUCTION
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y28 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws27">
               Data integration plays an important role in the analysis of high-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y29 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws28">
               throughput data. As the outputs of individual experiments can be
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y2a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws29">
               rather noisy, it is essential to look for ?ndings that are supported
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y2b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws2a">
               by several pieces of evidence to increase the signal and lessen
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y2c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws2b">
               the fraction of false positive ?ndings. The structure of the data
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y2d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws2c">
               and speci?c research questions largely dictate the methods used in
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y2e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws2d">
               integration. Still, some very general techniques for aggregation of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y2f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws2e">
               genomic data have been proposed such as the Bayesian networks
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y30 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws2f">
               (Troyanskaya 
               <span class="ffa ws30">et al.<span class="ff9">, 2003) and the Kernel methods (Bie </span>et al.</span>,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y31 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws31">
               2007). In this work, we limit ourselves to the situation where all
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y32 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws32">
               the data sources are represented as prioritized lists of genes. This is
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hc y33 ff8 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls8">
               ?
               <span class="ff9 fs2 ls9 ws33 v3">To whom correspondence should be addressed.</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb yb ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws34">
               a very natural way to represent a result of a genome-wide study and,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y34 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               therefore, ubiquitous in different types of analyzes.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y35 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws36">
               Finding a meaningful combination of different data sources is
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y36 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws37">
               often a non-trivial task. For example, differences in measurement
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y37 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws38">
               platforms and lab protocols can render gene expression levels
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y38 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws39">
               incomparable. Hence, it might be better to analyze different datasets
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y39 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3a">
               separately and then aggregate the resulting gene lists. Such a strategy
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y3a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3b">
               has been employed to ?nding gene co-expression networks (Lee
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y3b ffa fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3c">
               et al.
               <span class="ff9">, 2004; Stuart </span>et al.
               <span class="ff9">, 2003) and for de?ning more robust sets</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y3c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3d">
               of cancer-related genes (Grif?th 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2006).
               <span class="_ _7"> </span>Another example
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y3d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3e">
               is the study by Aerts 
               <span class="ffa ws3f">et al. </span>(2006), where the authors combined
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y3e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws40">
               different kinds of data sources to ?nd disease-related genes. For
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y3f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws41">
               this they ranked genes by similarity to the disease genes in the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y40 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws42">
               Gene Ontology (GO), pathways, transcription factor binding sites,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y41 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws43">
               sequence and literature and subsequently aggregated these rankings
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y42 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws44">
               to get the ?nal result. Boulesteix and Slawski (2009) used an
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y43 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws45">
               analogous methodology to combine results of differential expression
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y44 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               analysis.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y45 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws46">
               Combining preference lists into a single ranking is known as
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y46 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws47">
               rank aggregation. This problem has a rich history in the ?elds of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y47 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws48">
               information retrieval (Dwork 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2001a) and theory of social
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y48 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws49">
               choice (Copeland, 1951). In these contexts, the main focus is on the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y49 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws4a">
               ‘correctness’ of the resulting ranking. For example, in elections it is
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y4a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws4b">
               critical that each vote gets counted and represented in the ?nal result.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y4b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws4c">
               However, ?nding the best ranking is often computationally very
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y4c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws4d">
               expensive, for example the one that minimizes the misplacement
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y4d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws4e">
               or so-called ‘bubble sort distance’, and thus applicable only for a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y4e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws4f">
               relatively small class of problems. (Dwork 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2001b; Pihur 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y4f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               2007).
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y50 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws50">
               Data from high-throughput genomic experiments usually contains
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y51 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws51">
               a signi?cant proportion of noise and thus ‘correctness’ is not right
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y52 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws52">
               objective for these kinds of studies. For such settings, a good
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y53 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws53">
               rank aggregation method must be robust enough to ?nd a relevant
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y54 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws54">
               ranking even in the presence of unreliable or irrelevant inputs. Since
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y55 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws55">
               it possible that all rankings are meaningless in the context of a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y56 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws56">
               particular study, the method should also quantify the reliability or
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y57 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws57">
               signi?cance of the results. Finally, the method should be applicable
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y58 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws58">
               also for partial or top rankings only, since full rankings are often
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y59 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws59">
               unavailable, e.g. gene lists derived from articles or various tools and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y5a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               databases.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y5b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws5a">
               In this article, we propose a novel rank aggregation method
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y5c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws5b">
               based on order statistics that achieves all described objectives.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y5d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws5c">
               Stuart 
               <span class="ffa ws5d">et al. <span class="ff9">(2003) were the ?rst to utilize order statistics in</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y5e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws2c">
               rank aggregation. The computational scheme for their method was
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y5f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws5e">
               further optimized by Aerts 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>
               <span class="ws5f">(2006). This algorithm compares</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y60 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws60">
               the actual rankings with the expected behavior of uncorrelated
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hd y61 ff4 fs9 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws61">
               © The Author(s) 2012.
               <span class="_ _7"> </span>Published by Oxford University Press.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hd y62 ff4 fs9 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws62">
               This is an Open Access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hd y63 ff4 fs9 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws61">
               by-nc/3.0), which permits unrestricted non-commercial use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is pr
               <span class="_ _3"></span>operly cited.
              </div>
