            <div id="pf2" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="2">
             <div class="pc pc2 w0 h0">
              <div class="bi x5 y0 w1 he lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jaak_Vilo/publication/221749545/viewer/AS:267377099145216@1440759076403/background/2.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws0">
               [15:15 9/2/2012 Bioinformatics-btr709.tex]
               <span class="_ _0"> </span>Page:
               <span class="_ _1"> </span>574
               <span class="_ _2"> </span>573–580
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h4 y64 ff2 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               R.Kolde et al.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y65 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws64">
               rankings, re-ranks the items and assigns signi?cance scores. While
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y66 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws65">
               being robust to noise, this method requires simulations to de?ne
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y67 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws66">
               signi?cance thresholds (Aerts 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2006) and does not support
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y68 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               incomplete lists.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hb y69 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws67">
               To overcome these limitations, we propose a new algorithm that
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y6a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws31">
               is both computationally ef?cient and statistically stable. For each
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y6b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws68">
               item, the algorithm looks at how the item is positioned in the ranked
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y6c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws69">
               lists and compares this to the baseline case where all the preference
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y6d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws6a">
               lists are randomly shuf?ed. As a result, we assign a 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>-value for all
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y6e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws6b">
               items, showing how much better it is positioned in the ranked lists
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y6f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws6c">
               than expected by chance. This 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>-value is used both for re-ranking
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y70 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               the items and deciding their signi?cance.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hb y71 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws6d">
               We also extended this methodology to the case where only top
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y72 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws6e">
               elements in the lists are available. Compared with the common
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y73 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws6f">
               approach of counting the appearances of each item (Grif?th 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y74 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws70">
               2006; Lee 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2004), our method is clearly an improvement.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y75 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws71">
               It also takes into account the positional information and assigns
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y76 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               signi?cance levels to the ?ndings according to a theoretical model.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hb y77 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws72">
               All methods described in this article, including average rank and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y78 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws73">
               the method by Aerts 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>(2006), are implemented as a GNU R
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y79 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws74">
               package 
               <span class="ffb ws75">RobustRankAggreg</span>.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 ha y7a ff5 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsa">
               2
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>ROBUST RANK AGGREGATION
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y7b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws76">
               Let 
               <span class="ffa lsb">m</span>be the number of objects and 
               <span class="ffa lsc">n</span>be the number of preference
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y7c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws77">
               lists. For instance, 
               <span class="ffa lsd">n</span>might be the number of experiments and 
               <span class="ffa">m</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y7d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws78">
               the number of genes studied. Moreover, assume that in each survey
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y7e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws79">
               genes are ordered according to their impact so that the ones most
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y7f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws7a">
               likely to behave in a certain way are in the beginning of the list. Then
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y80 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws7b">
               the 
               <span class="ffa ws7c">rank </span>of a gene is just the position in this ordering. If we divide
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y81 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws7d">
               ranks by the maximal rank value 
               <span class="ffa lse">m</span>
               <span class="ws7e">, we obtain </span>
               <span class="ffa">normalized ranks</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y82 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws7f">
               with the maximal value of 1. For each gene let the corresponding
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hf y83 ffa fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws80">
               rank vector 
               <span class="ffc lsf">r<span class="ff8">=<span class="ff9 ls10">(</span></span></span>
               <span class="ls11">r<span class="ff9 fsa ls12 v5">1</span><span class="ff7 ls13 ws81 v0">,...,</span></span>
               <span class="ws75 v0">r<span class="fsa ls14 v5">n</span><span class="ff9 ws80">) be such that </span><span class="ls15">r<span class="fsa ls16 v5">j</span></span><span class="ff9 ws80">denotes the normalized</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y84 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               rank of the gene in the 
               <span class="ffa ls17">j</span>-th preference list.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hb y85 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws82">
               A general strategy for obtaining an aggregated preference list
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y86 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws83">
               is to score each rank vector somehow and order the genes based
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y87 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws84">
               on the scores. Note that relative ranks can be used even if the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y88 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws85">
               preference lists contain slightly different sets of genes. This is quite
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y89 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws86">
               a common scenario. For example, we might want to aggregate lists
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y8a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws87">
               from different microarray platforms where each of them measures a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y8b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws32">
               unique subset of genes. T
               <span class="_ _3"></span>o take this into account, we have to adjust
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y8c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws88">
               the maximal rank 
               <span class="ffa ls18">m</span>according to the number of elements in each
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y8d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws89">
               list in the normalization step and use a scoring method that produces
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y8e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               comparable scores even if the length of rank vector varies.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hb y8f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws8a">
               Classical rank aggregation methods try to maximize the coherence
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y90 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws8b">
               of the ?nal ranking with all the preferences. However, maximal
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y91 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws8c">
               coherence with all preferences is not always the best aggregation
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y92 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws8d">
               criterion, especially if some preferences are unreliable. Some
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y93 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws8e">
               ranking algorithms resolve this issue assuming that we can estimate
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y94 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws8f">
               correctness probability for each rank or preference list see, for
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y95 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws90">
               example Li 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>(2011). For most biological studies, this type
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y96 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws91">
               of extra information is not available. Also, each ranking is most
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y97 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws92">
               probably informative only on a subset of relevant genes, since
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y98 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws93">
               it re?ects only one aspect of the underlying biological question.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y99 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws94">
               Therefore, it is not reasonable to view an entire ranking as
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y9a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws95">
               informative or non-informative but rather make a distinction at the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y9b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws96">
               gene level. This can be achieved via ?xing a null model, which
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y9c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws97">
               describes distribution of ranks when all studies produce irrelevant
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y9d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               results, and estimate statistical signi?cance.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb y9e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws98">
               The simplest possible null model assumes that all studies are 
               <span class="ffa">non-</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y9f ffa fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws99">
               informative 
               <span class="ff9 ws2c">and produce randomly ordered gene lists. When genes</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ya0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9a">
               are ranked based solely on measurement data, the null model is
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ya1 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9b">
               equivalent to a permutation test, where measurements in each study
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ya2 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               are randomly relabeled before the analysis step.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 h10 ya3 ffd fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9c">
               2.1
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>Scoring rank vectors using order statistics
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ya4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9d">
               In most cases, we are interested in ?nding genes that are ranked
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ya5 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9e">
               highly in many preference lists ignoring a (small) fraction of non-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ya6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9f">
               informative studies. Thus, we can assume that all informative
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ya7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsa0">
               normalized ranks come from a distribution, which is strongly skewed
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ya8 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               toward zero and our task is to detect these distributions.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb ya9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsa1">
               For any normalized rank vector 
               <span class="ffc ws75">r</span>, let 
               <span class="ffa ws75">r</span>
               <span class="fsb ls1a wsa2 v5">(1)</span>
               <span class="ff7 ls13 ws81 v0">,...,<span class="ffa ls19">r</span></span>
               <span class="fsb ls1a v5">(<span class="ffa ls1b">n<span class="ff9 ls1c">)</span></span></span>
               <span class="v0">be a reordering</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 h11 yaa ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsa3">
               of 
               <span class="ffc ls1d">r</span>such that 
               <span class="ffa ls1e">r</span>
               <span class="fsb ls1a wsa4 v5">(1) </span>
               <span class="ff8 lsf v0">?<span class="ff7 ls13 ws81">...</span>?<span class="ffa ls1f">r</span></span>
               <span class="fsb ls1a v5">(<span class="ffa ls1b">n<span class="ff9 ls20">)</span></span></span>
               <span class="v0">. Then we can ask how probable it is</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 h12 yab ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsa5">
               to obtain 
               <span class="ff8 wsa6">ˆ<span class="_ _9"></span><span class="ffa ls21">r<span class="ff9 fsb ls22 v5">(<span class="ffa ls23">k<span class="ff9 ls24">)</span></span></span><span class="ff8 lsf v0">?<span class="ffa ls25">r<span class="ff9 fsb ls1a v5">(<span class="ffa ls23">k<span class="ff9 ls26">)</span></span></span><span class="ff9 ls9 wsa5">when the rank vector <span class="ff8 v0">ˆ</span></span></span></span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x9 hb yac ffc fs8 fc0 sc0 ls27">
               r
               <span class="ff9 ls9 wsa5">is generated by the null</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hf yad ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               model, i.e. all ranks 
               <span class="ff8 wsa6">ˆ<span class="_ _9"></span><span class="ffa ls28">r<span class="fsa ls29 v5">j</span><span class="ff9 ls9 ws35 v0">are sampled from uniform distribution.</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 h11 yae ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsa7">
               Let 
               <span class="ff7 wsa6">?<span class="ffa fsa ls2a v5">k</span><span class="fsa wsa8 v5">,<span class="ffa ls2b">n</span></span></span>
               <span class="ls10 v0">(<span class="ffc ls9 ws75">r</span><span class="ls9">) denote the probability that <span class="ff8 wsa6">ˆ<span class="_ _9"></span><span class="ffa ls2c">r<span class="ff9 fsb ls1a v5">(<span class="ffa ls23">k<span class="ff9 ls2d">)</span></span></span><span class="ff8 lsf">?</span><span class="ls25">r<span class="ff9 fsb ls1a v5">(<span class="ffa ls23">k<span class="ff9 ls2e">)</span></span></span><span class="ff9 ls9 wsa7">. Then under the</span></span></span></span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hf yaf ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsa9">
               null model the probability that the order statistic 
               <span class="ff8 wsa6">ˆ<span class="_ _9"></span><span class="ffa ws75">r<span class="ff9 fsb ls22 v5">(<span class="ffa ls23">k<span class="ff9 ls2f">)</span></span></span><span class="ff9 wsa9 v0">is smaller or</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yb0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               equal to 
               <span class="ffa ls30">x</span>can be expressed as a binomial probability
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xa h13 yb1 ff7 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls31">
               ?
               <span class="ffa fsa ls2a v5">k<span class="ff7 ls9 wsa8">,<span class="ffa ls32">n</span></span></span>
               <span class="ff9 ls10 v0">(<span class="ffa ls33">x</span><span class="lsf">)<span class="ff8 ls9">:=</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xb h14 yb2 ffa fsa fc0 sc0 ls9">
               n
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xc h15 yb3 ffe fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               ?
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xc h16 yb4 ff7 fsa fc0 sc0 ls9 wsa8">
               ?
               <span class="ff8">=<span class="ffa ls34">k</span><span class="ffe fs8 ws75 v6">?<span class="ffa v7">n</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xd h17 yb5 ff7 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls35">
               ?
               <span class="ffe ls9 ws75 v8">?</span>
               <span class="ffa ls36 v9">x</span>
               <span class="fsa ls37 v1">?</span>
               <span class="ff9 ls10 wsaa v9">(1<span class="ff8 ls38">?<span class="ffa ls33">x<span class="ff9 ls9 ws75">)</span><span class="fsa ls39 v4">n<span class="ff8 ls9 wsa8">?<span class="ff7 ls3a">?</span></span></span><span class="ff7 ls3b">,<span class="ff9 ls9">(1)</span></span></span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hf yb6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsab">
               since at least 
               <span class="ffa ls3c">k</span>normalized rankings must be in the range 
               <span class="ff8 wsa6">[</span>
               <span class="ws75">0<span class="ff7 ls13">,<span class="ffa ls33">x</span></span><span class="ff8 wsa6">]</span>.</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 h18 yb7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsac">
               Alternatively, 
               <span class="ff7 ls3d">?<span class="ffa fsa ls2a v5">k<span class="ff7 ls9 wsa8">,<span class="ffa ls2b">n</span></span></span></span>
               <span class="ls10 v0">(<span class="ffa ls33">x</span><span class="ls9 wsad">) can be expressed through a beta distribution, as</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hf yb8 ff8 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsa6">
               ˆ
               <span class="_ _9"></span>
               <span class="ffa ls3e">r<span class="ff9 fsb ls1a v5">(<span class="ffa ls23">k<span class="ff9 ls3f">)<span class="fs8 ls9 wsae va">is the order statistic of </span></span></span></span><span class="ls40 v0">n<span class="ff9 ls9 wsae">independent random variables uniformly</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hf yb9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               distributed over the range 
               <span class="ff8 wsa6">[</span>
               <span class="ws75">0<span class="ff7 ls13">,</span>1<span class="ff8 wsa6">]</span>.</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb yba ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsaf">
               Since the number of informative ranks is not known, we de?ne
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ybb ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               the ?nal score for the rank vector 
               <span class="ffc ls41">r</span>as the minimum of 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>-values
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xe hf ybc ff7 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls42">
               ?
               <span class="ff9 ls10">(<span class="ffc ls9 ws75">r</span><span class="lsf">)<span class="ff8 ls43">=</span><span class="ls9">min</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xf h19 ybd ffa fsa fc0 sc0 ls2a">
               k
               <span class="ff8 ls9 wsa8">=<span class="ff9 wsb0">1</span><span class="ff7">,...,</span></span>
               <span class="ls44">n<span class="ff7 fs8 ls45 v9">?</span></span>
               <span class="v2">k<span class="ff7 ls9 wsa8">,<span class="ffa ls32">n<span class="ff9 fs8 ls10 va">(<span class="ffc ls9 ws75">r<span class="ff9 wsb1">) (2)</span></span></span></span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ybe ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsb2">
               and order all rank vectors according to their 
               <span class="ff7 ls46">?</span>
               <span class="wsb3">scores. Illustration</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ybf ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsb4">
               of how the scores are calculated on two example genes is in the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yc0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               Figure 1.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb yc1 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsb5">
               As a minimum of 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>
               <span class="wsb6">-values, <span class="ff7 ls47">?</span></span>score itself is not a 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>
               <span class="wsb7">-value. Hence,</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yc2 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsb8">
               it must be corrected against bias coming from multiple hypothesis
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yc3 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsb9">
               testing to determine statistical signi?cance. Exact 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>-values can be
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yc4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsba">
               computed for each 
               <span class="ff7 ls48">?</span>score. However, the corresponding algorithm
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yc5 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsbb">
               relies on the same methods as Aerts 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>(2006) and thus inherits
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yc6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsbc">
               all weaknesses. In particular, it is computationally expensive and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yc7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsbd">
               becomes numerically unstable for rather small examples. A
               <span class="_ _7"> </span>full
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yc8 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               description of the method is given in the Supplementary Material.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb yc9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsbe">
               Alternatively, we can use Bonferroni correction for each 
               <span class="ff7 ls49">?</span>score
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yca ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsbf">
               separately to ?nd an upper bound on the associated 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>-value. For that
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ycb ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsc0">
               we must multiply each 
               <span class="ff7 ls4a">?</span>score with the number of input lists. Since
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ycc ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsc1">
               the number of input rankings is usually in the order of 10–100, the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ycd ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsc2">
               resulting correction is not overly stringent. Indeed, exact numerical
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yce ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsc3">
               comparisons between Bonferroni correction and actual 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>-values
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb ycf ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsc4">
               given in the Supplementary Material show upper bounds are very
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yd0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsc5">
               close to exact values. Thus, the Bonferroni correction is a good
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yd1 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               trade-off between ef?ciency and precision in most cases.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb yd2 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsc6">
               After the correction, we can decide whether the ranking of a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yd3 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsc7">
               particular gene is statistically signi?cant. T
               <span class="_ _3"></span>o ?nd all signi?cant
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yd4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsc8">
               genes, we have to correct derived (estimates of) 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>
               <span class="wsc9">-values further</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yd5 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               for multiple testing. This can be done we with standard methods.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb yd6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsca">
               From the computational viewpoint, the Robust Rank Aggregation
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yd7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wscb">
               (RRA) method is inexpensive. Its complexity is linear with respect
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yd8 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wscc">
               to the input size. Therefore, its applicability is not restricted by
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb yd9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               computational considerations.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1a y61 ff5 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               574
              </div>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,646,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:219.205977px;bottom:1103.675584px;width:42.152000px;height:8.999000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,646,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:296.287147px;bottom:1103.675584px;width:17.933000px;height:8.999000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,449,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:381.803054px;bottom:893.195656px;width:48.054000px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,449,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:74.816446px;bottom:875.655528px;width:17.933990px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,368,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:113.811579px;bottom:875.655528px;width:37.008980px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,368,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:182.934918px;bottom:875.655528px;width:17.934010px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,646,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:165.718128px;bottom:805.495019px;width:41.266990px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,646,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:241.866177px;bottom:805.495019px;width:17.933000px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,350,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:129.988045px;bottom:261.666242px;width:31.847000px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,350,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:192.288388px;bottom:261.666242px;width:17.601990px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,646,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:670.577364px;bottom:472.117361px;width:40.145000px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,646,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:744.031733px;bottom:472.117361px;width:17.933020px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
             </div>
             <div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.600523,0.000000,0.000000,1.600523,-77.145190,-172.376286]}"></div>
            </div> 
           </div> 
           <div class="pdf-viewer-page"> 
            <div id="pf3" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="3">
             <div class="pc pc3 w0 h0">
              <div class="bi x0 y0 w1 he lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jaak_Vilo/publication/221749545/viewer/AS:267377099145216@1440759076403/background/3.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws0">
               [15:15 9/2/2012 Bioinformatics-btr709.tex]
               <span class="_ _0"> </span>Page:
               <span class="_ _1"> </span>575
               <span class="_ _2"> </span>573–580
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x10 h4 y64 ff2 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               Robust rank aggregation
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x11 h1b yda fff fsc fc2 sc0 ls59">
               AB
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h1c ydb ffd fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 wscd">
               Fig. 1.
               <span class="_ _7"> </span>
               <span class="ff9 wsce">Visual description of RRA. (</span>
               <span class="ws4">A<span class="_ _3"></span><span class="ff9 wsce">) Shows an example of 20 ranked lists, with the positions of two genes highlighted. The ?rst gene is placed to the top</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h1c ydc ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws33">
               of the lists and the second distributed uniformly. (
               <span class="ffd ws4">B</span>) Shows in detail how 
               <span class="ff7 ls4b">?<span class="ffa fs0 ls4c v5">k<span class="ff7 ls9 wscf">,<span class="ffa ls4d">n</span></span></span></span>
               <span class="v0">scores change and how the <span class="ff7 ls4e">?</span>score is found.</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h10 ydd ffd fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9c">
               2.2
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>Aggregation of partial pr
               <span class="_ _3"></span>eference lists
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yde ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd0">
               In many cases, studies provide only partial rankings. For example,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb ydf ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd1">
               instead of all genes the list contains only the differentially expressed
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb ye0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd2">
               ones. Also, small ?uctuations in measurements can cause large
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb ye1 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd3">
               changes in the bottom part of such lists. Thus, it might be bene?cial
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb ye2 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               to keep only genes with statistically signi?cant changes.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb ye3 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd4">
               There are two ways to extend our basic algorithm. First, we can
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb ye4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd5">
               obtain a conservative approximation of the 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>
               <span class="wsd6">-values <span class="ff7 ls4f">?<span class="ffa fsa ls39 v5">n<span class="ff7 ls9 wsa8">,<span class="ffa ls50">k</span></span></span></span><span class="ls10 v0">(<span class="ffc ls9 ws75">r</span></span></span>
               <span class="v0">) and</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb ye5 ff7 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls51">
               ?
               <span class="ff9 ls9 wsd7">scores. Due to missing ranks we cannot correctly determine <span class="ffa ws75">r</span><span class="fsb ls22 v5">(<span class="ffa ls23">k<span class="ff9 ls52">)</span></span></span><span class="v0">.</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb ye6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsb6">
               However, if we replace all missing values with the maximal relative
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb ye7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd8">
               Rank 1, the resulting order statistics 
               <span class="ffa ls53">r</span>
               <span class="fsb ls1a v5">(<span class="ffa ls23">k<span class="ff9 ls54">)</span></span></span>
               <span class="v0">can only increase. Hence,</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb ye8 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd9">
               by inserting these estimates of 
               <span class="ffa ls55">r</span>
               <span class="fsb ls1a v5">(<span class="ffa ls23">k<span class="ff9 ls56">)</span></span></span>
               <span class="v0">into the Formula (1) we get</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb ye9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsda">
               upper bounds for all 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>
               <span class="wsdb">-values <span class="ff7 ls57">?<span class="ffa fsa ls39 v5">n<span class="ff7 ls9 wsa8">,<span class="ffa ls58">k</span></span></span></span><span class="ls10 v0">(<span class="ffc ls9 ws75">r</span></span></span>
               <span class="v0">). This approach is generally</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yea ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               applicable and suitable in most of the cases.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb yeb ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsdc">
               Alternatively, if we know the speci?c mechanism for eliminating
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yec ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsdd">
               ranks and the length of preference lists varies substantially, we
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yed ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsde">
               can incorporate data deletion directly into the null model. This
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yee ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsdf">
               provides more accurate and less conservative estimates of 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>-values.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yef ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse0">
               As a drawback, the results must be computed with dynamic
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yf0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse1">
               programming, which is slightly less ef?cient. Further details of this
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yf1 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               algorithm are shown in the Supplementary Material
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 ha yf2 ff5 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws26">
               3 RESUL
               <span class="_ _3"></span>TS
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h10 yf3 ffd fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9c">
               3.1
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>Simulation study
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yf4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse2">
               We used simulations to investigate basic properties of our method.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yf5 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse3">
               Namely, we generated rankings with planted elements that were
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yf6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse4">
               preferentially ranked at the top. T
               <span class="_ _3"></span>o add noise we included rankings
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yf7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse5">
               where the order of elements was completely random. Such data
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yf8 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse6">
               allows us to study two aspects. First, we can study whether
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yf9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse7">
               the resulting rankings separate planted elements from the others.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yfa ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse8">
               Second, we can determine how many planted elements are revealed
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yfb ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               and compare it with the performance of alternative methods.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb yfc ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse9">
               We compared our method with two alternatives: average rank
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yfd ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsea">
               and the method by Stuart 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>(2003). T
               <span class="_ _3"></span>o calculate the scores for
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb yfe ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wseb">
               Stuart method, we used the optimized algorithm from Aerts 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb yff ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsec">
               (2006). All three methods also provide signi?cance scores for ?nal
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y100 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsed">
               ranks showing how much higher a gene is placed in the inputs than
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y101 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               expected. Further details are given in Section 4.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y102 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsee">
               All rankings consisted of 1000 elements out of which 5% were
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y103 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsef">
               preferentially ranked at the top. W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e achieved that by associating
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y104 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsf0">
               randomly generated values to the elements and ordering them
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y105 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsf1">
               according to these. All values were drawn form normal distribution
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y106 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsf2">
               with unit variance. For planted elements, we chose the mean value
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hf y107 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsf3">
               from the exponential distribution with 
               <span class="ff7 lsf">?<span class="ff8">=</span></span>
               <span class="ws75">1<span class="ff7 wsa6">/</span></span>2 and used the standard
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y108 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               normal distribution for remaining elements.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y109 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsf4">
               For the ?rst test, we generated 10 such lists. As can be seen from
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y10a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsf5">
               Figure 2A, all three methods can order the lists very well, placing
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y10b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsf6">
               elements from the positive class at the top of the aggregated list.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y10c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsf7">
               Corresponding area under curve (AUC) scores are 0
               <span class="ff7 wsa6">.</span>
               <span class="wsf8">997, 0<span class="ff7 wsa6">.</span>995</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y10d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsf9">
               and 0
               <span class="ff7 wsa6">.</span>979 for Stuart method, RRA and rank average. However
               <span class="_ _3"></span>, the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y10e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsfa">
               results start to differ if we study the number of elements deemed
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y10f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsfb">
               signi?cant by each method using the false discovery rate of 0.05 as
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y110 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsfc">
               threshold (Fig. 2A). RRA
               <span class="_ _1"> </span>method outperformed rank average even
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y111 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsfd">
               with the data that does not contain any noise in the form of random
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y112 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               lists.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y113 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsfe">
               Stuart method has problems with signi?cance scoring. It produces
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y114 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsff">
               probability values for each element and the original article treats
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y115 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws100">
               them as 
               <span class="ffa ws75">P</span>, but actually they are not (Aerts 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2006). Using them
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y116 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               as 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>-values produces many false positives.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y117 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws101">
               In the second test, we studied resistance against noise. Figure 2B
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y118 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws102">
               shows the receiver-operating characteristic (ROC) curve for the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y119 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws103">
               three methods on data that contained 10 lists with signal as described
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y11a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws104">
               before and 30 randomly ordered lists. W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e can see that both RRA
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y11b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws105">
               and Stuart method perform considerably better than average rank
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y11c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws106">
               in ordering the lists, showing their robustness to this type of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y11d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               noise.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y11e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws107">
               We also tested the performance on recognizing planted elements
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y11f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws108">
               given various levels of noise (Fig. 2C). W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e generated 10 lists with
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y120 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws109">
               signal and added different numbers of randomly shuf?ed lists. In
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y121 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws10a">
               each case, we counted the number of true positive predictions on
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y122 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws10b">
               FDR level of 0.05. Because of the problems with signi?cance scores,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y123 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws10c">
               we omitted the Stuart method. Results show that RRA performs
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x13 h1a y61 ff5 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               575
              </div>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf2" data-dest-detail="[2,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,727,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:424.754711px;bottom:558.673624px;width:5.482980px;height:7.079000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf8" data-dest-detail="[8,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,941,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:210.670390px;bottom:142.076776px;width:42.680000px;height:8.999010px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf8" data-dest-detail="[8,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,941,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:288.342153px;bottom:142.076776px;width:17.934000px;height:8.999010px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,646,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:418.802352px;bottom:124.536649px;width:40.832000px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,646,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:517.625020px;bottom:756.397403px;width:17.933000px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf4" data-dest-detail="[4,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,619,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:554.960412px;bottom:563.457586px;width:5.483000px;height:7.079000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf4" data-dest-detail="[4,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,619,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:602.359889px;bottom:458.216822px;width:5.484000px;height:7.080010px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,646,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:723.473052px;bottom:370.517785px;width:39.069000px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,646,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:793.151788px;bottom:370.517785px;width:17.932990px;height:9.000000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf4" data-dest-detail="[4,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,619,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:883.582917px;bottom:335.437531px;width:5.483000px;height:7.078990px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf4" data-dest-detail="[4,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,619,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:716.241875px;bottom:195.118096px;width:5.483000px;height:7.079010px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
             </div>
             <div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.600523,0.000000,0.000000,1.600523,-77.145190,-172.376286]}"></div>
            </div> 
           </div> 
           <div class="pdf-viewer-page"> 
            <div id="pf4" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="4">
             <div class="pc pc4 w0 h0">
              <div class="bi x5 y0 w1 he lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jaak_Vilo/publication/221749545/viewer/AS:267377099145216@1440759076403/background/4.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws0">
               [15:15 9/2/2012 Bioinformatics-btr709.tex]
               <span class="_ _0"> </span>Page:
               <span class="_ _1"> </span>576
               <span class="_ _2"> </span>573–580
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h4 y64 ff2 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               R.Kolde et al.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x14 h1d y124 fff fsd fc2 sc0 ls9">
               A
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x14 h1d y125 fff fsd fc2 sc0 ls5d">
               BC
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1c y126 ffd fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws10d">
               Fig. 2.
               <span class="_ _7"> </span>
               <span class="ff9 ws10e">Results from a simulation study. (<span class="ffd">A) </span>Shows signi?cance scores calculated with different methods on the 10 lists, which contained 50 planted elements.</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y127 ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws10f">
               The number of true and false positives was computed on FDR level of 0
               <span class="ff7 ws110">.</span>05. Both methods based on order statistics (RRA and Stuart) separate planted elements
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y128 ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws111">
               from noise better than average rank. Still, the Stuart method produces many false positives and thus cannot be used for deciding the signi?cance of genes.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1c y129 ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls5a">
               (
               <span class="ffd ls9 ws4">B</span>
               <span class="ls9 ws112">) Shows ROC curves of different methods on noisy data (10 lists with signal, 30 random). Methods based on order statistics outperform the average rank</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1c y12a ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws113">
               considerably. (
               <span class="ffd ws4">C</span>
               <span class="ws114">) Shows the number of true positives given at different levels of noise.<span class="_ _1"> </span>At each level, we simulated 10 datasets. RRA shows much higher</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y12b ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws33">
               resistance to noise than an average rank. The Stuart method was excluded from (C) as it failed to identify planted elements from noise.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1c y12c ffd fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1f">
               Fig. 3.
               <span class="_ _7"> </span>
               <span class="ff9 ws115">The proportion of planted elements that were correctly identi?ed by</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y12d ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws116">
               RRA given different numbers of top elements available in input rankings.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y12e ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws117">
               The gray line shows the proportion of planted elements in the inputs. W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e can
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y12f ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws118">
               see that the number of correctly identi?ed elements starts to drop only after
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y130 ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws24">
               almost the whole list is dropped. Therefore, by using partial instead of full
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y131 ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws33">
               rankings we usually lose very little information.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y132 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws119">
               consistently better than average rank and gives meaningful results
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y133 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               even if the levels of noise are relatively high.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hb y134 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws11a">
               Finally, we studied how well the RRA
               <span class="_ _7"> </span>method works if we
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y135 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws11b">
               consider only 
               <span class="ff7 ls5b">?</span>top ranking elements. T
               <span class="_ _3"></span>o answer this question, we
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y136 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws11c">
               simulated datasets with 10 lists with planted elements as described
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y137 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws11d">
               before. W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e cut out different proportions of top elements and counted
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y138 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws11e">
               the number of statistically signi?cant results as given by RRA. The
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y139 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsdc">
               outcome is in Figure 3. As before 5% of the elements were planted.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y13a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd8">
               A full list allowed us to identify about three-fourths of them. This
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y13b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws11f">
               number started to fall only when we removed &gt;95% of the elements
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y13c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws120">
               in the bottom of rankings. But, even with top-1% lists, we can on
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y13d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws121">
               average correctly identify about half of the planted elements. It must
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y13e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws122">
               be noted that the statistics are still correct using top-
               <span class="ff7 ls5c">?</span>
               <span class="ws123">lists. The</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y13f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               number of false positives was well within the allowed limits.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb y140 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws124">
               In summary, we can conclude that RRAis usable also in situations
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y141 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               where complete rankings are unavailable.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 h10 y142 ffd fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9c">
               3.2
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>Predicting pathway members with knock-out data
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y143 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws125">
               Gene expression measurements before and after some transcription
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y144 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws126">
               factor knockouts reveal important information about genomic
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y145 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws101">
               pathways. However, we cannot infer the pathway members directly
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y146 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws127">
               from this data. W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e can only identify putative targets for these
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y147 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws42">
               factors. T
               <span class="_ _3"></span>o identify pathway members, we must join target lists of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y148 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws98">
               all factors related to a particular pathway. However
               <span class="_ _3"></span>, these target lists
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y149 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws128">
               are inherently noisy, since a knockout often affects genes that do not
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1a y61 ff5 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               576
              </div>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf4" data-dest-detail="[4,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,412,null]">
               <div class="d m1" style="border-width:1.000000px;border-style:solid;border-color:rgb(0,0,0);position:absolute;left:613.265850px;bottom:440.502237px;width:5.483000px;height:7.079010px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
             </div>
             <div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.600523,0.000000,0.000000,1.600523,-77.145190,-172.376286]}"></div>
            </div> 
           </div> 
           <div class="pdf-viewer-page"> 
            <div id="pf5" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="5">
             <div class="pc pc5 w0 h0">
              <div class="bi x0 y0 w1 he lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jaak_Vilo/publication/221749545/viewer/AS:267377099145216@1440759076403/background/5.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws0">
               [15:15 9/2/2012 Bioinformatics-btr709.tex]
               <span class="_ _0"> </span>Page:
               <span class="_ _1"> </span>577
               <span class="_ _2"> </span>573–580
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x10 h4 y64 ff2 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               Robust rank aggregation
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h1c y14a ffd fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws129">
               Fig. 4.
               <span class="_ _7"> </span>
               <span class="ff9 ws12a">Predicting genes to a GO category based on the knockouts of its transcription factors. A gene name on the <span class="ffa ls5e">x</span>-axis corresponds to a knockout and each</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h1e y14b ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws12b">
               bubble represents the Fisher’s exact test 
               <span class="ffa ls5f">P</span>-value, showing the enrichment of the knock-out affected genes in the GO category
               <span class="_ _3"></span>. The horizontal line shows the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h1e y14c ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws12c">
               same enrichment 
               <span class="ffa ls5f">P</span>-value for the aggregated list. The size of the bubble corresponds to the number of regulated genes in the knockout and the color shows
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h1e y14d ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws12d">
               if the 
               <span class="ffa ls5f">P</span>-value is signi?cant. The 
               <span class="ffa ls5f">P</span>-values show that the aggregated list is more enriched in the genes related to the corresponding process than most of the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h1e y14e ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               inputs.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y14f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws12e">
               correspond to the pathway. By robust rank aggregation, we can ?lter
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y150 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               out genes that are not speci?c for the process.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb y151 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws12f">
               We used yeast data by Hu 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>(2007) to validate this approach.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y152 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws130">
               The data consist of experiments where the transcription factors are
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y153 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws131">
               knocked out one by one. Reimand 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>(2010) analyzed the data
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y154 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws132">
               and published the lists of genes where expression was most affected
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y155 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws133">
               by each knockout. W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e used these lists to predict members of the GO
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y156 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws134">
               groups. For each GO group, we identi?ed the transcription factors
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y157 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws135">
               related to the group and extracted corresponding gene lists. Next we
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y158 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws136">
               used our methods to compile a list of statistically signi?cant targets.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y159 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws137">
               As a quality control, we used Fisher’s exact test on each list to
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y15a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws138">
               estimate the enrichment of the known members of the functional
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y15b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws139">
               group. Figure 4 depicts results for cell cycle and response to
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y15c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               chemical stimulus.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb y15d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws2a">
               In both cases, aggregated lists are more enriched with genes
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y15e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws13a">
               belonging to the GO category of interest than most of the individual
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y15f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws13b">
               lists. Although, a particular knockout can outperform the aggregated
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y160 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws13c">
               list, the impact of less informative lists is limited. Generally, we do
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y161 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws13d">
               not know in advance which experiment is most informative and thus
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y162 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               aggregation is a good way to consolidate data.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb y163 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws13e">
               Results with response to chemical stimulus demonstrate the utility
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y164 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws13f">
               of robustness of our rank aggregation method. Only 6 of 39 of the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y165 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws140">
               input rankings were enriched with genes related to the category. Still,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y166 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws141">
               our method recognized the signal among all that noise and returned
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y167 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               a list with signi?cant enrichment.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 h10 y168 ffd fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9c">
               3.3
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>MEM project
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y169 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws142">
               Our method is already used in the Multi Experiment Matrix (MEM)
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y16a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws143">
               web server (Adler 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2009), which searches for co-expressed
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y16b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws144">
               genes over large collections of microarray data. Given a gene name,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y16c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws145">
               the web server performs a co-expression query in hundreds of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y16d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               datasets and then aggregates the results using the RRA algorithm.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb y16e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws146">
               To demonstrate the usefulness of rank aggregation in this setting
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y16f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws147">
               we performed the following study. The goal was to ?nd transcription
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y170 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws42">
               factor targets by searching for genes that are co-expressed with it.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y171 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws148">
               As a gold standard, we used targets found by ChIP-seq study Chen
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y172 ffa fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws149">
               et al. 
               <span class="ff9 ws14a">(2008). The study covered 15 embryonic stem cell-related</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y173 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws14b">
               transcription regulators. W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e performed the co-expression search
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y174 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws14c">
               with these 15 genes on 12 ES-related mouse datasets and recorded
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y175 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws14d">
               both individual and aggregated search results. For each of those we
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y176 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws14e">
               calculated ROC AUC scores showing prediction accuracy
               <span class="_ _3"></span>. W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e used
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y177 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws14f">
               both RRA and Stuart method for this.
               <span class="_ _a"> </span>The AUC values are close
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hf y178 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws150">
               to one if the prediction for the gold standard is good and 
               <span class="ff8 wsa6">?</span>0.5 if
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y179 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws151">
               the gold standard cannot be predicted. The results can be seen in
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y17a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               Figure 5.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y17b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws152">
               Generally, the aggregated list outperforms most of the input lists
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y17c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws153">
               but not all. For CTF, MYCS and SMAD1 queries, results of the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y17d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws154">
               RRA algorithm are in the middle of pack. However
               <span class="_ _3"></span>, in all those
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hf y17e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws123">
               cases AUC scores for input lists are dispersed 
               <span class="ff8 wsa6">?</span>0.5, i.e. there is
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y17f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws155">
               no signal. This explains the poor performance of our algorithm: it
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y180 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws156">
               can only amplify the signal if it is present in the input. So if we
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y181 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws157">
               could tell in advance what input is the most relevant, then we could
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y182 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws158">
               completely omit the aggregation step. However, pinpointing good
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y183 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws159">
               lists is not feasible in most cases. Even in our example, the best
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y184 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws15a">
               individual dataset is different for each transcription factor. Hence, it
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y185 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               is safer to include all the data and use the aggregated results.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 h10 y186 ffd fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9c">
               3.4
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>Comparison with other methods
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y187 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws15b">
               The RRA algorithm has four key features: it is robust to noise, it can
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y188 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws15c">
               handle incomplete rankings, it assigns a signi?cance score to each
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y189 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws15d">
               element in the resulting ranking, and it is also ef?cient to compute.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y18a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws15e">
               All these features are important in practice; in particular, if one wants
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y18b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               to build a tool for interactive data analysis.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y18c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws15f">
               To our knowledge, other available methods cannot match these
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y18d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws160">
               properties. Classical rank aggregation methods are often sensitive
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y18e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws161">
               to noise (as illustrated in Fig. 2) and do not identify the relevant
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y18f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws162">
               part of the aggregated ranking. In addition, some of them can be
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y190 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               computationally very expensive (Dwork 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2001b).
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y191 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws163">
               The Stuart method is a good alternative to RRA, as it is robust
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y192 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws164">
               to noise (Fig. 2A
               <span class="_ _a"> </span>and B). The rankings produced by Stuart and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y193 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws165">
               RRA algorithms are very similar in terms of discrimination. The
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y194 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws166">
               Stuart algorithm yields ROC AUC scores that are comparable if
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y195 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws167">
               not a bit better than RRA (Figs 2 and 5). This is an expected
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y196 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws168">
               result, as the statistics are very similar while Stuart’s method takes
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y197 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws169">
               more information into account. However, the scores of the Stuart
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y198 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws147">
               method are not directly 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>-values (Aerts 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2006) and closed form
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x13 h1a y61 ff5 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               577
              </div>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,404,null]">

              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf7" data-dest-detail="[7,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,556,null]">

              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf6" data-dest-detail="[6,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,810,null]">
