           <div class="pdf-viewer-page"> 
            <div id="pf6" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="6">
             <div class="pc pc6 w0 h0">
              <div class="bi x5 y0 w1 he lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jaak_Vilo/publication/221749545/viewer/AS:267377099145216@1440759076403/background/6.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws0">
               [15:15 9/2/2012 Bioinformatics-btr709.tex]
               <span class="_ _0"> </span>Page:
               <span class="_ _1"> </span>578
               <span class="_ _2"> </span>573–580
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h4 y64 ff2 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               R.Kolde et al.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1c y199 ffd fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws16a">
               Fig. 5. 
               <span class="ff9 ws16b">AUC scores when predicting transcription factor targets based on</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y19a ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws16c">
               gene co-expression. The gray dots represent the individual results and black
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y19b ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws16d">
               dots and plus signs aggregated results with RRA and Stuart method. These
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y19c ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws16e">
               values show that in the presence of a signal in the inputs, aggregation methods
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y19d ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws16f">
               pick it up and outperform most of the inputs. When the signal is low in the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1f y19e ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws170">
               input (AUC 
               <span class="ff8 ws110">?</span>0.5), aggregated results are not considerably better. The results
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y19f ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws171">
               for RRA and Stuart method are almost identical, since they use very similar
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1e y1a0 ff9 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws33">
               criteria for aggregation.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1a1 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws172">
               solutions are not known. Hence, extensive simulations are needed
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1a2 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws173">
               to assess the signi?cance of aggregated ranks. These results are not
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1a3 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws174">
               easily pre-calculable, since we need simulations for each shape of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1a4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws175">
               the rank matrix. As a consequence, the Stuart method with proper
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1a5 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws176">
               thresholding is hundreds if not thousands times slower than the RRA
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1a6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               algorithm.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hb y1a7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws177">
               The Stuart method does not handle missing ranks. This can be
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1a8 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws178">
               resolved with a small modi?cation shown in the Supplementary
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1a9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws179">
               Material. Finally, the algorithm can become numerically unstable
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1aa ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws17a">
               when the number of lists is bigger. In our experience, it happens
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1ab ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws17b">
               around 40–50 input lists (see Supplementary Material for examples),
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1ac ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               but depending on the data this number can be also smaller.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hb y1ad ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws17c">
               As a ?nal test, we used updated Stuart’s method on the knock-out
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1ae ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws17d">
               data by making some adjustments for it to work in this setting. Out
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1af ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws17e">
               of 15 cases, where we reached a signi?cant result, in 11 cases the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1b0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws17f">
               RRA had the same or better enrichment score (see Supplementary
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1b1 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               Material for details) showing the utility of RRA approach.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hb y1b2 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws180">
               In summary, the unique properties of RRA
               <span class="_ _7"> </span>make it suitable
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1b3 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws181">
               for a variety of practical situations for which there are no good
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1b4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws182">
               alternatives available. Our tests show that even in the cases where
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1b5 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws183">
               some alternatives could be used, our method gives comparable
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1b6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               results.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 ha y1b7 ff5 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsa">
               4
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>MATERIALS AND METHODS
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h10 y1b8 ffd fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9c">
               4.1
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>Rank aggregation methods used in comparisons
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y169 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsda">
               We used average rank and the method by S
               <span class="_ _3"></span>tuart 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>(2003) for
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y16a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws184">
               evaluating RRA. T
               <span class="_ _3"></span>o assign signi?cance scores for average ranks,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y16b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws185">
               note that the resulting rank follows normal distribution with mean
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h20 y16c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws186">
               0.5, and SD 
               <span class="ff8 ls60 v9">?</span>
               <span class="ws75 v0">1<span class="ff7 wsa6">/</span>12<span class="ffa ls61">n</span><span class="ws187">, provided that samples come from uniform</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1b9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               distribution.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hb y1ba ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws188">
               The method by Stuart 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>(2003) outputs in our notation
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h21 y1bb ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws189">
               a probability Pr
               <span class="ff8 ls66 ws18a">[ˆ<span class="_ _9"></span><span class="ffa ls9 ws75">r<span class="ff9 fsb ls1a ws18b v5">(1) </span><span class="ff7 lsf v0">&lt;<span class="ffa ls62">r<span class="ff9 fsb ls1a wsa2 v5">(1)</span></span><span class="ls13 ws81">,...,<span class="ff8 ls9 wsa6">ˆ<span class="_ _9"></span><span class="ffa ws75">r<span class="ff9 fsb ls1a v5">(<span class="ffa ls1b">n<span class="ff9 ls63">)</span></span></span><span class="ff7 lsf">&lt;</span><span class="ls64">r<span class="ff9 fsb ls1a v5">(<span class="ffa ls1b">n<span class="ff9 ls20">)</span></span></span><span class="ff8 ls65">]</span></span><span class="ff9 ws18c">where <span class="ff8 v0">ˆ</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x15 hb y1bc ffc fs8 fc0 sc0 ls65">
               r
               <span class="ff9 ls9 ws189">is a sample from</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1bd ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws18d">
               standard uniform distribution as an output score. W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e tried to
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1be ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws18e">
               use this probability as a signi?cance 
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>-value, as was done in
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1bf ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws18f">
               the original article, although permutation tests would have been
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hb y1c0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws190">
               more appropriate to assign signi?cance scores. Since the formulas
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1c1 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws191">
               used in the original article are computationally very demanding,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1c2 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws192">
               we used the algorithm proposed by Aerts 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>
               <span class="ws193">(2006). Both</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1c3 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws194">
               these methods are also implemented in the associated GNU R
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1c4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws74">
               package 
               <span class="ffb ws75">RobustRankAggreg</span>.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 h10 y1c5 ffd fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9c">
               4.2
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>Pathway prediction
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1c6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws195">
               For pathway prediction, we used the statistical analysis results
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1c7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws196">
               from Reimand 
               <span class="ffa ws5a">et al. </span>(2010) that are available in ArrayExpress
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1c8 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws197">
               (accession: E-MTAB-109).
               <span class="_ _1"> </span>We used false discovery rate of 0
               <span class="ff7 wsa6">.</span>05 as
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1c9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws198">
               the signi?cance cutoff when de?ning the lists. The response of the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1ca ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws101">
               chemical stimulus gene list was downloaded as a GO slim category
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1cb ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws199">
               from Saccharomyces Genome Database (Hong 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2008) and cell
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1cc ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               cycle genes from a review by de Lichtenberg 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>(2005).
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 h10 y1cd ffd fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9c">
               4.3
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>Stem cell study using MEM
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1ce ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws19a">
               A gold standard for transcription factor targets were obtained from
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1cf ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws19b">
               the study by Chen 
               <span class="ffa">et al. </span>(2008). The article de?ned an association
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1d0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws19c">
               score between each gene and a transcription factor that varied from
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1d1 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws89">
               0 to 1. As scores showed a clear bimodal distribution, we considered
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1d2 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws19d">
               all genes with a score &gt;0
               <span class="ff7 wsa6">.</span>6 to be targets of the corresponding
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1d3 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               transcription factor.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb y1d4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws19e">
               In the MEM webtool (http://biit.cs.ut.ee/mem), we selected 12
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1d5 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws19f">
               datasets on mouse Affymetrix platform 430 2.0. Since the ChIP-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1d6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a0">
               seq study was performed on mouse embryonic stem (ES) cells, we
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1d7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a1">
               selected only the datasets that mentioned ES cell in their description.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1d8 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               The list of datasets is available in the Supplementary Material.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb y1d9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a2">
               We queried each of the transcription factors, for which we had
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1da ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a3">
               binding information, separately. The MEM webtool performed a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1db ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a4">
               similarity search on each dataset using correlation distance between
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1dc ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws38">
               the transcription factor and other genes. The resulting lists of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1dd ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               correlated genes were used in aggregation and assessing the AUC.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb y1de ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws6f">
               To combine the data from ChIP-seq with co-expression queries,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1df ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws46">
               we translated all the results into Ensembl gene identi?ers using
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1e0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               g:Convert (Reimand 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2007).
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 ha y1e1 ff5 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws26">
               5 DISCUSSION
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 h10 y1e2 ffd fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws9c">
               5.1
               <span class="_ _8"> </span>Gene expression meta-analysis
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1e3 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a5">
               The accumulation of gene expression studies has created a situation
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1e4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a6">
               where one can pose new questions about the co-expression and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1e5 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a7">
               functional role of genes by integrating the already existing data
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1e6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a8">
               (Wren, 2009). It is also easier to answer some biological questions
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1e7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1a9">
               by reanalyzing and combining old datasets rather than redoing
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1e8 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1aa">
               experiments. For example, meta-analysis of gene expression data
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1e9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1ab">
               has been successfully used for studying cancer and its subtyping
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1ea ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws72">
               (Rhodes 
               <span class="ffa ws35">et al.</span>
               <span class="ws1ac">, 2002; Wirapati <span class="ffa ws35">et al.<span class="ff9">, 2008).</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hb y1eb ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1ad">
               There are two general strategies for meta-analysis. The ?rst
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1ec ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1ae">
               involves rigorous normalization, integration and analysis of the raw
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1ed ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1af">
               expression datasets. In general, this is the preferred type; however, it
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1ee ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b0">
               might not be always practical. The main problem is the availability
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1ef ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b1">
               of the data. Many older publications do not have the data uploaded
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1f0 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b2">
               to public repositories, such as ArrayExpress (Parkinson 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2009)
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1f1 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b3">
               or GEO (Barrett 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2009). Even from the data that is available in
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1f2 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b4">
               these repositories, about two-thirds might be unusable for meta-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1f3 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b5">
               analysis due to poor quality or missing raw ?les (Larsson and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1f4 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b6">
               Sandberg, 2006). Another problem is caused by the usage of dif
               <span class="_ _3"></span>ferent
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1f5 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b7">
               microarray platforms. Each platform uses different technology to
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 hb y1f6 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b8">
               measure the expression and features its own set of probes and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1a y61 ff5 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9">
               578
              </div>
              <a class="l" href="publication/221749545_Robust_Rank_Aggregation_for_gene_list_integration_and_meta-analysis#pf8" data-dest-detail="[8,&quot;XYZ&quot;,null,941,null]">

            <div id="pf7" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="7">
             <div class="pc pc7 w0 h0">
              <div class="bi x0 y0 w1 he lazyload" data-bg="profile/Jaak_Vilo/publication/221749545/viewer/AS:267377099145216@1440759076403/background/7.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 h2 y1 ff1 fs0 fc0 sc0 ls0 ws0">
               [15:15 9/2/2012 Bioinformatics-btr709.tex]
               <span class="_ _0"> </span>Page:
               <span class="_ _1"> </span>579
               <span class="_ _2"> </span>573–580
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x10 h4 y64 ff2 fs2 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws3">
               Robust rank aggregation
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y65 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws69">
               genes. Therefore, proper integration of gene expression values over
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y66 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               platforms is very dif?cult, although, doable in special cases.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb y67 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1b9">
               The second option is to merge only the published results. This way
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y68 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1ba">
               we can avoid normalization problems caused by different platforms
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y69 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1bb">
               and also improve the data availability dramatically, since most of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y6a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wse9">
               the microarray publications include a gene list or a signature of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y6b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1bc">
               some sort. On the downside, this approach introduces many potential
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y6c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1bd">
               sources of noise arising from different preprocessing, normalization
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y6d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               and statistical analysis steps (Cahan 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2007).
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb y6e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1be">
               Commonly used methods for integrating published gene lists are
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y6f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1bf">
               usually very simple. Sometimes, the aggregated list is obtained by
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y70 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1c0">
               counting the number of times each gene occurs in the input lists
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y71 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1c1">
               (Grif?th 
               <span class="ffa ws1c2">et al.<span class="ff9">, 2006; Miller and Stamatoyannopoulos, 2010). Rank</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y72 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1c3">
               aggregation methods are an obvious choice and several of them have
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y73 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1c4">
               also been tried in this setting (DeConde 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>, 2006; Pihur 
               <span class="ffa">et al.</span>,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y74 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1c5">
               2008). Generally, these methods give reasonable results but there
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y75 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1c6">
               are different drawbacks. Counting-based methods do not naturally
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y76 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1c7">
               take into account the ranked nature of the gene lists, although, there
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y77 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsd4">
               are some workarounds. Many of the rank aggregation methods are
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y78 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1c8">
               computationally very expensive, making some questions intractable
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y79 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1c9">
               (Dwork 
               <span class="ffa ws1ca">et al.<span class="ff9">, 2001b). Most of the classical methods also lack</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y1f7 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1cb">
               robustness, which is critical, since some input sources can be dubious
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y1f8 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1cc">
               due to differences in clinical and experimental setups, etc. The main
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y1f9 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1cd">
               problem with all the methods is the lack of a statistical model for
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y1fa ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               assessing the relevance of the results.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb y1fb ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1ce">
               Our RRA algorithm ?ts very well to this meta-analytic setting.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y1fc ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1cf">
               Most importantly, it is based on a statistical model that naturally
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y1fd ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsb9">
               allows evaluating the signi?cance of the results. In addition, RRA
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y1fe ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d0">
               is easy to compute and robust, not restricting its use to certain
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y1ff ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d1">
               subset of problems or requiring all data to be of top quality. The
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y200 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d2">
               RRA algorithm can also handle variable gene content of different
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y201 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d3">
               microarray platforms. By de?ning the rank vector for each gene
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y202 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d4">
               based only on the datasets where it is present, we do not have to
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y203 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               omit the genes that are not present in every platform.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 ha y204 ff5 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws26">
               6 CONCLUSIONS
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y205 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d5">
               Ranked lists of genes are a common output of a vast array of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y206 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d6">
               bioinformatics tools. Often, the same question can be answered
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y207 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d7">
               using several datasets or algorithms producing multiple lists of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y208 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws36">
               genes and there is a need to combine the results. In this article,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y209 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d8">
               we present a novel rank aggregation algorithm RRA that is very
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y20a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1d9">
               well suited for such bioinformatic settings. The aggregation is based
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y20b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws17a">
               on the comparison of actual data with a null model that assumes
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y20c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1da">
               random order of input lists. A
               <span class="_ _a"> </span>
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>
               <span class="ws1db">-value assigned to each element</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y20d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1dc">
               in the aggregated list described how much better it was ranked than
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y20e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1dd">
               expected. This provides basis for reordering and identi?es signi?cant
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y20f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1de">
               elements. As the
               <span class="_ _7"> </span>
               <span class="ffa lsa">P</span>
               <span class="ws1df">-value calculation procedure takes into account</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y210 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e0">
               only the best ranks for each factor, the method is very robust, which
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y211 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               is important when using high-throughput data.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hb y212 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e1">
               We validated the method both on simulated and biological data.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y213 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e2">
               The simulations showed that the algorithm can very well retrieve the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y214 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e3">
               positive factors planted into the input lists, even in the presence of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y215 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e4">
               noise. The method still managed to ?nd some of the planted factors,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y216 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e5">
               even if over 75% of the input rankings did not contain any relevant
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y217 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e6">
               information. W
               <span class="_ _3"></span>e also showed that the method can work with partial
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y218 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e7">
               rankings as well. In fact, we can omit very large parts of the input
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x0 hb y219 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               lists without in?uencing the results at all.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hb y21a ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e8">
               In the two case studies on biological data, we found that RRA
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y21b ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1e9">
               can amplify the biological signal if it exists in the input data. The
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y21c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1ea">
               aggregated ranking displays stronger signal than most of the inputs
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y21d ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1eb">
               lists.
               <span class="_ _b"> </span>Even if some of the inputs may perform well individually,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y21e ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1ec">
               we are in practice often better off by taking into account all the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y21f ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1ed">
               possible information rather than trying to guess the most informative
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y220 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws1ee">
               source. All the methods described here have been implemented and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3 hb y221 ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws35">
               are available in additional GNU R package
               <span class="_ _6"> </span>
               <span class="ffb ws75">RobustRankAggreg</span>.
              </div>

                  <li class="c-list-item li-publication no-preview includes-citation-list" itemprop="citation" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle" data-reactid="18">
                   <meta itemprop="datePublished" content="2017-12-01" data-reactid="19">

                   <meta itemprop="name" content="Analysis of microRNA (miRNA) expression profiles reveals 11 key biomarkers associated with non-small cell lung cancer" data-reactid="21">
                   <div class="indent-right" data-reactid="22"></div>
                   <ul class="citation-contexts" data-reactid="23">
                    <li class="citation-context-item" data-reactid="24"><span class="citation-context-text" data-reactid="25">
                      <!-- react-text: 26 -->p &lt; 0.05 was considered as threshold for significance identification. For a better consistence of the identified miRNAs, we applied a novel robust rank aggregation method—RobustRankAggreg of R package
                      <!-- /react-text --><span class="citation-context-reference" data-reactid="27">[21]</span>
                      <!-- react-text: 28 -->. In this method, one p value to each element was assigned to indicate how prior it is when compared to a null model. 
                      <!-- /react-text --></span>
                     <div class="citation-enriched-context-actions clearfix" data-reactid="29"></div></li>
                   </ul>
                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="30">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="31"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/319921058_Analysis_of_microRNA_miRNA_expression_profiles_reveals_11_key_biomarkers_associated_with_non-small_cell_lung_cancer" data-reactid="32"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="33">Analysis of microRNA (miRNA) expression profiles reveals 11 key biomarkers associated with non-small cell lung cancer</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="34">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="35"><a href="#" data-reactid="36">
                      <!-- react-text: 37 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 38 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="39"><a href="#" data-reactid="40">
                      <!-- react-text: 41 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 42 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 43 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="44"><strong data-reactid="45">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 46 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 47 -->Background Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) accounts for more than 85% of lung cancer cases which cause most of cancer-related deaths globally. However, the results vary largely in different studies due to different platforms and sample sizes. Here, we aim to identify the key miRNAs in the carcinogenesis of NSCLC that might be potential biomarkers for this cancer. Methods Meta-analysis was performed on miRNA profile using seven datasets of NSCLC studies. Furthermore, we predicted and investigated the functions of genes regulated by key miRNAs. Results Eleven key miRNAs were identified, including 2 significantly upregulated ones (hsa-miR-21-5p and hsa-miR-233-3p) and 9 downregulated ones (hsa-miR-126-3p, hsa-miR-133a-3p, hsa-miR-140-5p, hsa-miR-143-5p, hsa-miR-145-5p, hsa-miR-30a-5p, hsa-miR-30d-3p, hsa-miR-328-3pn, and hsa-miR-451). The functional enrichment analysis revealed that both up- and downregulated miRNAs were proportionally associated with regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter. According to transcription factor analysis, there were 65 (43.9%) transcription factors influenced by both up- and downregulated miRNAs. Conclusions In this study, 11 meta-signature miRNAs, as well as their target genes and transcription factors, were found to play significant role in carcinogenesis of NSCLC. These target genes identified in our study may be profitable to diagnosis and prognostic prediction of NSCLC as biomarkers. Electronic supplementary material The online version of this article (10.1186/s12957-017-1244-y) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>

                  <li class="c-list-item li-publication no-preview includes-citation-list" itemprop="citation" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle" data-reactid="76">

                   <meta itemprop="image" content="https://www.researchgate.net/images/template/default_publication_preview_big.png" data-reactid="78">
                   <meta itemprop="name" content="Quality Enhancement by Weighted Rank Aggregation of Crowd Opinion" data-reactid="79">
                   <div class="indent-right" data-reactid="80"></div>
                   <ul class="citation-contexts" data-reactid="81">
                    <li class="citation-context-item" data-reactid="82"><span class="citation-context-text" data-reactid="83">
                      <!-- react-text: 84 -->Therefore, aggregation of those rankings is very much needed to produce final ranking. Rank aggregation (DeConde et al. 2006;Dwork et al. 2001;Stuart et al. 2003;
                      <!-- /react-text --><span class="citation-context-reference" data-reactid="85">Kolde et al. 2012;</span>
                      <!-- react-text: 86 -->Chen et al. 2013) has been studied in depth over the years for combining multiple alternatives so as to apply in diverse research applications including bioinformatics, crowdsourcing, etc. In some crowdsourcing studies (Hovy et al. 2013;Ipeirotis 2010;Liu, Peng, and Ihler 2013;Nguyen et al. 2016;Chatterjee and Bhattacharyya 2017), there is a need to find consensus from multiple crowdsourced opinions. 
                      <!-- /react-text --></span>
                     <div class="citation-enriched-context-actions clearfix" data-reactid="87"></div></li>
                   </ul>
                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="88">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="89"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/319415990_Quality_Enhancement_by_Weighted_Rank_Aggregation_of_Crowd_Opinion" data-reactid="90"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="91">Quality Enhancement by Weighted Rank Aggregation of Crowd Opinion</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="92">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="93"><a href="#" data-reactid="94">
                      <!-- react-text: 95 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 96 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="97"><a href="#" data-reactid="98">
                      <!-- react-text: 99 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 100 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 101 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="102"><strong data-reactid="103">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 104 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 105 -->Expertise of annotators has a major role in crowdsourcing based opinion aggregation models. In such frameworks, accuracy and biasness of annotators are occasionally taken as important features and based on them priority of the annotators are assigned. But instead of relying on a single feature, multiple features can be considered and separate rankings can be produced to judge the annotators properly. Finally, the aggregation of those rankings with perfect weightage can be done with an aim to produce better ground truth prediction. Here, we propose a novel weighted rank aggregation method and its efficacy with respect to other existing approaches is shown on artificial dataset. The effectiveness of weighted rank aggregation to enhance quality prediction is also shown by applying it on an Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT) dataset.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>
                   </div>

                    <li class="citation-context-item" data-reactid="141"><span class="citation-context-text" data-reactid="142">
                      <!-- react-text: 143 -->For example,[91]presents a ranking algorithm that betters existing ranking model based on the assignment of P-value. As stated by
                      <!-- /react-text --><span class="citation-context-reference" data-reactid="144">[91]</span>
                      <!-- react-text: 145 -->it detects genes that are ranked consistently better than expected under null hypothesis of uncorrelated inputs and assigns a significance score for each gene. The underlying probabilistic model makes the algorithm parameter free and robust to outliers, noise and errors.

                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="147">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="148"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/319255562_Sensitivity_analysis_based_ranking_reveals_unknown_biological_hypotheses_for_down_regulated_genes_in_time_buffer_during_administration_of_PORCN-WNT_inhibitor_ETC-1922159_in_CRC" data-reactid="149"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="150">Sensitivity analysis based ranking reveals unknown biological hypotheses for down regulated genes in time buffer during administration of PORCN-WNT inhibitor ETC-1922159 in CRC</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="151">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="152"><a href="#" data-reactid="153">
                      <!-- react-text: 154 -->[Show description] 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 155 -->
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="156"><a href="#" data-reactid="157">
                      <!-- react-text: 158 -->[Hide description] 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 159 -->
                      <!-- /react-text --></a><span data-reactid="160"><strong data-reactid="161">DESCRIPTION:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 162 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 163 -->Background: The search and wet lab testing of unknown/unexplored/untested biological hypotheses in the form of combinations of various intra/extracellular factors that are involved in a signaling pathway, costs a lot in terms of time, investment and energy. Currently, a major problem in biology is to cherry pick the combinations based on expert advice, literature survey or guesses to investigate a particular combinatorial hypothesis. Methods: In a recent development of the PORCN-WNT inhibitor ETC-1922159 for colorectal cancer, a list of down-regulated genes were recorded in a time buffer after the administration of the drug. The regulation of the genes were recorded individually but it is still not known which higher (? 2) order interactions might be playing a greater role after the administration of the drug. In order to reveal the priority of these higher order interactions among the down-regulated genes or the likely unknown biological hypotheses, a search engine was developed based on the sensitivity indices of the higher order interactions that were ranked using a support vector ranking algorithm and sorted. Results: For example, LGR family (Wnt signal enhancer) is known to neutralize RNF43 (Wnt inhibitor). After the administration of ETC-1922159 it was found that using HSIC (and rbf, linear and laplace variants of kernel) the rankings of the interaction between LGR5-RNF43 were 61, 114 and 85 respectively. Rankings for LGR6-RNF43 were 1652, 939 and 805 respectively. The down-regulation of LGR family after the drug treatment is evident in these rankings as it takes bottom priorities for LGR5-RNF43 interaction. The LGR6-RNF43 takes higher ranking than LGR5-RNF43, indicating that it might not be playing a greater role as LGR5 during the Wnt enhancing signals. These rankings confirm the efficacy of the proposed search engine design. Conclusion: Prioritized unknown biological hypothesis form the basis of further wet lab tests with the aim to reduce the cost of (1) wet lab experiments (2) combinatorial search and (3) lower the testing time for biologist who search for influential interactions in a vast combinatorial search forest. From in silico perspective, a framework for a search engine now exists which can generate rankings for nth order interactions in Wnt signaling pathway, thus revealing unknown/untested/unexplored biological hypotheses and aiding in understanding the mechanism of the pathway. The generic nature of the design can be applied to any signaling pathway or phenomena under investigation where a prioritized order of interactions among the involved factors need to be investigated for deeper understanding. Future improvements of the design are bound to facilitate medical specialists/oncologists in their respective investigations.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span>
                     <!-- react-text: 164 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --></span>
                   </div>

                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="195">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="196"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/318446428_Clinical_value_of_integrated-signature_miRNAs_in_esophageal_cancer" data-reactid="197"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="198">Clinical value of integrated-signature miRNAs in esophageal cancer</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="199">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="200"><a href="#" data-reactid="201">
                      <!-- react-text: 202 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 203 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="204"><a href="#" data-reactid="205">
                      <!-- react-text: 206 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 207 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 208 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="209"><strong data-reactid="210">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 211 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 212 -->MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are crucial regulators of gene expression in tumorigenesis and are of great interest to researchers, but miRNA profiles are often inconsistent between studies. The aim of this study was to confirm candidate miRNA biomarkers for esophageal cancer from integrated-miRNA expression profiling data and TCGA (The Cancer Genome Atlas) data in tissues. Here, we identify five significant miRNAs by a comprehensive analysis in esophageal cancer, and two of them (hsa-miR-100-5p and hsa-miR-133b) show better prognoses with significant difference for both 3-year and 5-year survival. Additionally, they participate in esophageal cancer occurrence and development according to KEGG and Panther enrichment analyses. Therefore, these five miRNAs may serve as miRNA biomarkers in esophageal cancer. Analysis of differential expression for target genes of these miRNAs may also provide new therapeutic alternatives in esophageal cancer.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>
                   </div>

                      <!-- react-text: 245 -->These techniques have a long history starting with de Borda (1781). Recent methodological contributions, primarily Markov chain-based and cross entropy Monte Carlo-based methods, can be found inDwork et al. (2001), DeConde et al. (2006), Sculley (2007, Lin and Ding (2009), Lin (2010b), and

                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="249">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="250"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/317622501_A_novel_method_for_estimating_the_common_signals_for_consensus_across_multiple_ranked_lists" data-reactid="251"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="252">A novel method for estimating the common signals for consensus across multiple ranked lists</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="253">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="254"><a href="#" data-reactid="255">
                      <!-- react-text: 256 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 257 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="258"><a href="#" data-reactid="259">
                      <!-- react-text: 260 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 261 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 262 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="263"><strong data-reactid="264">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 265 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 266 -->The ranking of objects, such as journals, institutions or biological entities, is broadly used to assess the relative quality or relevance of such objects. A multiple ranking is performed by a number of assessors (humans or machines) and inference about the nature of the observed rankings is desirable for evaluation, business or scientific purposes. The assessors’ decisions are based on some inherent metric scale and depend on judgement and discriminatory ability, data to which we usually do not have access. An indirect inference approach is proposed that allows one to estimate those signal parameters that might be causal for the observed rankings obtained from several assessors, some of which may not necessarily provide the same decision quality. The order of the values represents a consensus ranking across the observed individual rankings. The standard errors of the estimated signal parameters are obtained through a non-parametric bootstrap. Hence, the signal variability can be evaluated object-wise for the purpose of quantifying the stability of the associated rank positions. As a result, such signal estimates can be used in the meta-analysis of conceptually similar evaluation exercises, studies or experiments, and in any data integration task where measurements on the metric scale are either unavailable, or not directly comparable. The suggested approach is validated on simulated rank data as well as on experimental rank data from current molecular medicine. The proposed algorithms were implemented and all calculations performed in the R environment. The source code is provided.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>
                   </div>

                  <li class="c-list-item li-publication no-preview includes-citation-list" itemprop="citation" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/ScholarlyArticle" data-reactid="291">

                   <meta itemprop="image" content="https://www.researchgate.net/images/template/default_publication_preview_big.png" data-reactid="293">
                   <meta itemprop="name" content="Querying Probabilistic Preferences in Databases" data-reactid="294">
                   <div class="indent-right" data-reactid="295"></div>
                   <ul class="citation-contexts" data-reactid="296">
                    <li class="citation-context-item" data-reactid="297"><span class="citation-context-text" data-reactid="298">
                      <!-- react-text: 299 -->Request permissions from permissions@acm.org.'17, May 14-19, 2017, Chicago, ILmation about the relative expression levels of genes in a cell may provide evidence that groups of genes are involved in a common biological pathway[1,
                      <!-- /react-text --><span class="citation-context-reference" data-reactid="300">22,</span>
                      <!-- react-text: 301 -->34]. Preferences are often inferred from indirect input (e.g., a ranked list may be inferred from individual choices), and are therefore uncertain in nature. 
                      <!-- /react-text --></span>
                     <div class="citation-enriched-context-actions clearfix" data-reactid="302"></div></li>
                   </ul>
                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="303">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="304"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/316849724_Querying_Probabilistic_Preferences_in_Databases" data-reactid="305"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="306">Querying Probabilistic Preferences in Databases</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="307">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="308"><a href="#" data-reactid="309">
                      <!-- react-text: 310 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 311 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="312"><a href="#" data-reactid="313">
                      <!-- react-text: 314 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 315 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 316 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="317"><strong data-reactid="318">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 319 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 320 -->We propose a novel framework wherein probabilistic preferences can be naturally represented and analyzed in a probabilistic relational database. The framework augments the relational schema with a special type of a relation symbol---a preference symbol. A deterministic instance of this symbol holds a collection of binary relations. Abstractly, the probabilistic variant is a probability space over databases of the augmented form (i.e., probabilistic database). Effectively, each instance of a preference symbol can be represented as a collection of parametric preference distributions such as Mallows. We establish positive and negative complexity results for evaluating Conjunctive Queries (CQs) over databases where preferences are represented in the Repeated Insertion Model (RIM), Mallows being a special case. We show how CQ evaluation reduces to a novel inference problem (of independent interest) over RIM, and devise a solver with polynomial data complexity.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>
                   </div>
                   <div class="publication-meta publication-meta" data-reactid="321">
                    <!-- react-text: 322 -->Conference Paper 
                    <!-- /react-text -->
                    <!-- react-text: 323 -->· May 2017 
                    <!-- /react-text -->
                    <!-- react-text: 324 -->· Computational Statistics &amp; Data Analysis
                    <!-- /react-text -->

(function(){widgetLoader.createInitialWidget({"data":{"publicationFulltextFallbackViewer":null,"publicationUid":221749545,"abstract":"The continued progress in developing technological platforms, availability of many published experimental datasets, as well as different statistical methods to analyze those data have allowed approaching the same research question using various methods simultaneously. To get the best out of all these alternatives, we need to integrate their results in an unbiased manner. Prioritized gene lists are a common result presentation method in genomic data analysis applications. Thus, the rank aggregation methods can become a useful and general solution for the integration task.\nStandard rank aggregation methods are often ill-suited for biological settings where the gene lists are inherently noisy. As a remedy, we propose a novel robust rank aggregation (RRA) method. Our method detects genes that are ranked consistently better than expected under null hypothesis of uncorrelated inputs and assigns a significance score for each gene. The underlying probabilistic model makes the algorithm parameter free and robust to outliers, noise and errors. Significance scores also provide a rigorous way to keep only the statistically relevant genes in the final list. These properties make our approach robust and compelling for many settings.\nAll the methods are implemented as a GNU R package RobustRankAggreg, freely available at the Comprehensive R Archive Network http:\/\/cran.r-project.org\/.","publicationHeader":{"data":{"title":"Robust Rank Aggregation for gene list integration and (function(){widgetLoader.createInitialWidget({"data":{"publicationUid":221749545,"abstract":"The continued progress in developing technological platforms, availability of many published experimental datasets, as well as different statistical methods to analyze those data have allowed approaching the same research question using various methods simultaneously. To get the best out of all these alternatives, we need to integrate their results in an unbiased manner. Prioritized gene lists are a common result presentation method in genomic data analysis applications. Thus, the rank aggregation methods can become a useful and general solution for the integration task.\nStandard rank aggregation methods are often ill-suited for biological settings where the gene lists are inherently noisy. As a remedy, we propose a novel robust rank aggregation (RRA) method. Our method detects genes that are ranked consistently better than expected under null hypothesis of uncorrelated inputs and assigns a significance score for each gene. The underlying probabilistic model makes the algorithm parameter free and robust to outliers, noise and errors. Significance scores also provide a rigorous way to keep only the statistically relevant genes in the final list. These properties make our approach robust and compelling for many settings.\nAll the methods are implemented as a GNU R package RobustRankAggreg, freely available at the Comprehensive R Archive Network = MAT: Linking transcription factor expression and DNA binding data","type":"Article","abstract":"Transcription factors are proteins that bind to motifs on the DNA and thus affect gene expression regulation. The qualitative description of the corresponding processes is therefore important for a better understanding of essential biological mechanisms. However, wet lab experiments targeted at the discovery of the regulatory interplay between transcription factors and binding sites are...","longerAbstract":"Transcription factors are proteins that bind to motifs on the DNA and thus affect gene expression regulation. The qualitative description of the corresponding processes is therefore important for a better understanding of essential biological mechanisms. However, wet lab experiments targeted at the discovery of the regulatory interplay between transcription factors and binding sites are expensive. We propose a new, purely computational method for finding putative associations between transcription factors and motifs. This method is based on a linear model that combines sequence information with expression data. We present various methods for model parameter estimation and show, via experiments on simulated data, that these methods are reliable. Finally, we examine the performance of this model on biological data and conclude that it can indeed be used to discover meaningful associations. The developed software is available as a web tool and Scilab source code at Pathway animations for high-throughput data","type":"Article","abstract":"Gene expression analysis with microarrays has become one of the most widely used high-throughput methods for gathering genome-wide functional data. Emerging -omics fields such as proteomics and interactomics introduce new information sources. With the rise of systems biology, researchers need to concentrate on entire complex pathways that guide individual genes and related processes....","longerAbstract":"Gene expression analysis with microarrays has become one of the most widely used high-throughput methods for gathering genome-wide functional data. Emerging -omics fields such as proteomics and interactomics introduce new information sources. With the rise of systems biology, researchers need to concentrate on entire complex pathways that guide individual genes and related processes. Bioinformatics methods are needed to link the existing knowledge about pathways with the growing amounts of experimental data.\nWe present KEGGanim, a novel web-based tool for visualizing experimental data in biological pathways. KEGGanim produces animations and images of KEGG pathways using public or user uploaded high-throughput data. Pathway members are coloured according to experimental measurements, and animated over experimental conditions. KEGGanim visualization highlights dynamic changes over conditions and allows the user to observe important modules and key genes that influence the pathway. The simple user interface of KEGGanim provides options for filtering genes and experimental conditions. KEGGanim may be used with public or private data for 14 organisms with a large collection of public microarray data readily available. Most common gene and protein identifiers and microarray probesets are accepted for visualization input.\nhttp:\/\/biit.cs.ut.ee\/KEGGanim\/.","url":"publication\/5792250_KEGGanim_Pathway_animations_for_high-throughput_data","clickMilestone":"TsBFVW7KpXND7gxXPC-X83LrnXGr4GYCNy0xWO-a5gwsIiJVOsIeYttxsvxSV0DaBhqr0D2ZxWh0JPlQJsdbGXzORm18uIPrJeWZUCvT","publicationFiguresAuthorList":{"data":{"publicationUid":5792250,"totalCount":6,"initialDisplayCount":4,"defaultImages":{"defaultImageSmallURL":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4951093203564\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_s.jpg","defaultImageURL":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4671872220764\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_m.jpg","defaultImageURL2x":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/437738464651637\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_l.jpg"},"isLoggedIn":false,"isStatic":true},"templateName":"publicliterature\/PublicationFiguresAuthorList","templateHash":null,"id":"rgw36_59d973db91b21","widgetId":"rgw36_59d973db91b21","widgetUrl":"https:\/\/www.researchgate.net\/publicliterature.PublicationFiguresAuthorList.html?isStatic=1","stylesheets":[],"_isReact":true},"journal":{"abbrev":"BIOINFORMATICS","articleInfluenceScore":3.571000000000000174082970261224545538425445556640625,"catAuthor":null,"citedHalfLife":"6.9","eigenfactorScore":0.19672000000000000596855898038484156131744384765625,"fiveYearImpactFactor":8.135999999999999232613845379091799259185791015625,"id":null,"immediacyIndex":1.173999999999999932498440102790482342243194580078125,"impactFactor":4.9809999999999998721023075631819665431976318359375,"issn":"1367-4811","journalId":40517,"journalUrl":"http:\/\/bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org\/","linkingIssn":null,"publisher":{"conditions":["Pre-print ","enforceShowingCompleteContext":true}},"additionalCssClasses":["includes-citation-list"],"abstract":"Background\nNon-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) accounts for more than 85% of lung cancer cases which cause most of cancer-related deaths globally. However, the results vary largely in different studies due to different platforms and sample sizes. Here, we aim to identify the key miRNAs in the carcinogenesis of NSCLC that might be potential biomarkers for this cancer.\n\nMethods\nMeta-analysis was performed on miRNA profile using seven datasets of NSCLC studies. Furthermore, we predicted and investigated the functions of genes regulated by key miRNAs.\n\nResults\nEleven key miRNAs were identified, including 2 significantly upregulated ones (hsa-miR-21-5p and hsa-miR-233-3p) and 9 downregulated ones (hsa-miR-126-3p, hsa-miR-133a-3p, hsa-miR-140-5p, hsa-miR-143-5p, hsa-miR-145-5p, hsa-miR-30a-5p, hsa-miR-30d-3p, hsa-miR-328-3pn, and hsa-miR-451). The functional enrichment analysis revealed that both up- and downregulated miRNAs were proportionally associated with regulation of transcription from RNA polymerase II promoter. According to transcription factor analysis, there were 65 (43.9%) transcription factors influenced by both up- and downregulated miRNAs.\n\nConclusions\nIn this study, 11 meta-signature miRNAs, as well as their target genes and transcription factors, were found to play significant role in carcinogenesis of NSCLC. These target genes identified in our study may be profitable to diagnosis and prognostic prediction of NSCLC as biomarkers.\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (10.1186\/s12957-017-1244-y) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.","description":false,"hasMicroData":true,"isResearch":false,"isFulltext":true,"isSlurp":false,"isNoText":false,"hideAbstract":false,"hideTypeIcons":false,"publicationType":"Article","fileCategory":"Full-text","publicationDate":"Dec 2017","publicationFullDate":"2017-12-01","journal":null,"publicationItemClickMilestone":"QDcFKqQYqJKXnV0Vj7BUKfzIscPhub8wqM3gO9PuIhqSTn4-6blRWg","publicationImage":"https:\/\/www.researchgate.net\/images\/template\/default_publication_preview_big.png"},"319415990":{"publicationUid":319415990,"publicationKey":"319415990_Quality_Enhancement_by_Weighted_Rank_Aggregation_of_Crowd_Opinion","authorsPartOne":[{"id":1514157,"url":"profile\/Sujoy_Chatterjee2","fullname":"Sujoy Chatterjee","imageUrl":"https:\/\/i1.rgstatic.net\/ii\/profile.image\/AS%3A363287679127555%401463625940554_m\/Sujoy_Chatterjee2.jpg"},{"id":1914219,"url":"profile\/Anirban_Mukhopadhyay3","fullname":"Anirban Mukhopadhyay","imageUrl":"https:\/\/i1.rgstatic.net\/ii\/profile.image\/AS%3A272407516676130%401441958421963_m\/Anirban_Mukhopadhyay3.jpg"},{"id":2105728294,"url":"scientific-contributions\/2105728294_Malay_Bhattacharyya","fullname":"Malay Bhattacharyya","imageUrl":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4951093203564\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_s.jpg"}],"authorsPartTwo":[],"surplusAuthors":null,"url":"publication\/319415990_Quality_Enhancement_by_Weighted_Rank_Aggregation_of_Crowd_Opinion","title":"Quality Enhancement by Weighted Rank Aggregation of Crowd Opinion","additionalRightSideTopWidgets":{"type":"enriched","data":{"nextDetailPagePayload":null,"context":" final ranking. In such frameworks, accuracy and biasness of annotators are occasionally taken as important features and based on them priority of the annotators are assigned. But instead of relying on a single feature, multiple features can be considered and separate rankings can be produced to judge the annotators properly. Finally, the aggregation of those rankings with perfect weightage can be done with an aim to produce better ground truth prediction. Here, we propose a novel weighted rank aggregation method and its efficacy with respect to other existing approaches is shown on artificial dataset. ","enforceShowingCompleteContext":true}},"additionalCssClasses":["includes-citation-list"],"abstract":null,"description":"Background:\nThe search and wet lab testing of unknown\/unexplored\/untested biological hypotheses in the form of combinations of various intra\/extracellular factors that are involved in a signaling pathway, costs a lot in terms of time, investment and energy. Currently, a major problem in biology is to cherry pick the combinations based on expert advice, literature survey or guesses to investigate a particular combinatorial hypothesis.\n\nMethods:\nIn a recent development of the PORCN-WNT inhibitor ETC-1922159 for colorectal cancer, a list of down-regulated genes were recorded in a time buffer after the administration of the drug. The regulation of the genes were recorded individually but it is still not known which higher (\u2265 2) order interactions might be playing a greater role after the administration of the drug. In order to reveal the priority of these higher order interactions among the down-regulated genes or the likely unknown biological hypotheses, a search engine was developed based on the sensitivity indices of the higher order interactions that were ranked using a support vector ranking algorithm and sorted.\n\nResults: \nFor example, LGR family (Wnt signal enhancer) is known to neutralize RNF43 (Wnt inhibitor). After the administration of ETC-1922159 it was found that using HSIC (and rbf, linear and laplace variants of kernel) the rankings of the interaction between LGR5-RNF43 were 61, 114 and 85 respectively. Rankings for LGR6-RNF43 were 1652, 939 and 805 respectively. The down-regulation of LGR family after the drug treatment is evident in these rankings as it takes bottom priorities for LGR5-RNF43 interaction. The LGR6-RNF43 takes higher ranking than LGR5-RNF43, indicating that it might not be playing a greater role as LGR5 during the Wnt enhancing signals. These rankings confirm the efficacy of the proposed search engine design.\n\nConclusion:\nPrioritized unknown biological hypothesis form the basis of further wet lab tests with the aim to reduce the cost of (1) wet lab experiments (2) combinatorial search and (3) lower the testing time for biologist who search for influential interactions in a vast combinatorial search forest. From in silico perspective, a framework for a search engine now exists which can generate rankings for nth order interactions in Wnt signaling pathway, thus revealing unknown\/untested\/unexplored biological hypotheses and aiding in understanding the mechanism of the pathway. The generic nature of the design can be applied to any signaling pathway or phenomena under investigation where a prioritized order of interactions among the involved factors need to be investigated for deeper understanding. Future improvements of the design are bound to facilitate medical specialists\/oncologists in their respective investigations.","hasMicroData":true,"isResearch":true,"isFulltext":true,"isSlurp":false,"isNoText":false,"hideAbstract":false,"hideTypeIcons":false,"publicationType":"Working Paper","fileCategory":"Full-text","publicationDate":"Aug 2017","publicationFullDate":"2017-08-22","journal":"Computational Statistics & Data Analysis","publicationItemClickMilestone":"2JDfFK9BodfRenP5DJgIVcDNJDfQGGxck9AJ2EiJuqkxeB8XB6anSA","publicationImage":"https:\/\/www.researchgate.net\/images\/template\/default_publication_preview_big.png"},"318446428":{"publicationUid":318446428,"publicationKey":"318446428_Clinical_value_of_integrated-signature_miRNAs_in_esophageal_cancer","authorsPartOne":[{"id":2130546771,"url":"scientific-contributions\/2130546771_Heng-Chao_Zhang","fullname":"Heng-Chao Zhang","imageUrl":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4951093203564\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_s.jpg"},{"id":2063199,"url":"profile\/Kai-Fu_Tang","fullname":"Kai-Fu Tang","imageUrl":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4951093203564\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_s.jpg"}],"authorsPartTwo":[],"surplusAuthors":null,"url":"publication\/318446428_Clinical_value_of_integrated-signature_miRNAs_in_esophageal_cancer","title":"Clinical value of integrated-signature miRNAs in esophageal cancer","additionalRightSideTopWidgets":{"type":"enriched","data":{"nextDetailPagePayload":null,"context":"The novel RRA method[8], based on the leave-one-out cross-validation and Bonferroni correction, assigns a P-value to each miRNA in the last aggregated list. ","enforceShowingCompleteContext":true}},"additionalCssClasses":["includes-citation-list"],"abstract":"MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are crucial regulators of gene expression in tumorigenesis and are of great interest to researchers, but miRNA profiles are often inconsistent between studies. The aim of this study was to confirm candidate miRNA biomarkers for esophageal cancer from integrated-miRNA expression profiling data and TCGA (The Cancer Genome Atlas) data in tissues. Here, we identify five significant miRNAs by a comprehensive analysis in esophageal cancer, and two of them (hsa-miR-100-5p and hsa-miR-133b) show better prognoses with significant difference for both 3-year and 5-year survival. Additionally, they participate in esophageal cancer occurrence and development according to KEGG and Panther enrichment analyses. Therefore, these five miRNAs may serve as miRNA biomarkers in esophageal cancer. ","enforceShowingCompleteContext":true}},"additionalCssClasses":["includes-citation-list"],"abstract":"The ranking of objects, such as journals, institutions or biological entities, is broadly used to assess the relative quality or relevance of such objects. A multiple ranking is performed by a number of assessors (humans or machines) and inference about the nature of the observed rankings is desirable for evaluation, business or scientific purposes. The assessors\u2019 decisions are based on some inherent metric scale and depend on judgement and discriminatory ability, data to which we usually do not have access. An indirect inference approach is proposed that allows one to estimate those signal parameters that might be causal for the observed rankings obtained from several assessors, some of which may not necessarily provide the same decision quality. The order of the values represents a consensus ranking across the observed individual rankings. The standard errors of the estimated signal parameters are obtained through a non-parametric bootstrap. Hence, the signal variability can be evaluated object-wise for the purpose of quantifying the stability of the associated rank positions. As a result, such signal estimates can be used in the meta-analysis of conceptually similar evaluation exercises, studies or experiments, and in any data integration task where measurements on the metric scale are either unavailable, or not directly comparable. The suggested approach is validated on simulated rank data as well as on experimental rank data from current molecular medicine. The proposed algorithms were implemented and all calculations performed in the R environment. The source code is provided.","description":false,"hasMicroData":true,"isResearch":false,"isFulltext":true,"isSlurp":false,"isNoText":false,"hideAbstract":false,"hideTypeIcons":false,"publicationType":"Article","fileCategory":"Full-text","publicationDate":"Jun ","enforceShowingCompleteContext":true}},"additionalCssClasses":["includes-citation-list"],"abstract":"We propose a novel framework wherein probabilistic preferences can be naturally represented and analyzed in a probabilistic relational database. The framework augments the relational schema with a special type of a relation symbol---a preference symbol. A deterministic instance of this symbol holds a collection of binary relations. Abstractly, the probabilistic variant is a probability space over databases of the augmented form (i.e., probabilistic database). Effectively, each instance of a preference symbol can be represented as a collection of parametric preference distributions such as Mallows. We establish positive and negative complexity results for evaluating Conjunctive Queries (CQs) over databases where preferences are represented in the Repeated Insertion Model (RIM), Mallows being a special case. We show how CQ evaluation reduces to a novel inference problem (of independent interest) over RIM, and devise a solver with polynomial data complexity.","description":false,"hasMicroData":true,"isResearch":false,"isFulltext":false,"isSlurp":false,"isNoText":true,"hideAbstract":false,"hideTypeIcons":false,"publicationType":"Conference In the context of the Web, the main applications include building meta-search engines, combining ranking functions, selecting documents based on multiple criteria, and improving search precision through word associations. We develop a set of techniques for the rank aggregation problem and compare their performance to that of well-known methods. A primary goal of our work is to design rank aggregation techniques that can effectively combat \"spam,\" a serious problem in Web searches. Experiments show that our methods are simple, efficient, and
